newsitem.title: USA: Valentine cargo flying despite Ecuador troubles.
newsitem.headline: Valentine cargo flying despite Ecuador troubles.

text.p: Air cargo, including exports of cut flowers for Valentine's Day, was still moving in and out of Ecuador on Friday, despite Ecuador's political problems and work stoppages.

But air cargo executives said they were watching developments warily on Friday as the days before Valentine's Day are a peak time for air cargo out of Ecuador, a major producer of cut flowers, with many orders for roses and other blossoms.
Ecuador's Vice President Rosalia Arteaga on Sunday was appointed head of a caretaker government that brought an end to the political crisis sparked by the ouster of flamboyant leader Abdala Bucaram.
Legislators said Congress would meet on Tuesday to pass legislation allowing it to reappoint its leader, Fabian Alarcon, as president, with Arteaga returning to the vice-presidency.

Bucaram, dubbed "El Loco" -- "madman" -- for his sometimes bizarre behavior, stepped down early on Sunday just six months after he won office, driven out by a paralyzing strike and a revolt in the Congress.
A general strike that began on Wednesday slowed the shipping of flowers, and on Friday some exporters said they were having trouble getting flowers to the airport.
"Some of the flowers are getting hot, and you just cannot have that," William Surplus, vice president of Sunburst Farms, Miami, a major importer of flowers, said.
But Spohrer said the strike had no effect on Challenge and his shipments were arriving as scheduled.
"We see no cause for concern at this time," said B.F. Spohrer, president of Challenge Air Cargo. But, he added, "We are watching it closely." Challenge has two daily flights out of Ecuador.

Last week an executive at Fine Air said that Fine had stopped flying to Ecuador for a few days because of the political problems. But the airline resumed its daily flight Friday morning without incident. -- Reuters Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+ 5017
